elements.content: Coordination polymers show great potential for the tailored design of advanced photonic applications by employing crystal chemistry concepts. One challenge for achieving a rational design of nonlinear optically active MOF materials is deriving fundamental structure–property relations of the interplay between the photonic properties and the spatial arrangements of optically active chromophores within the network. We here investigate two-photon-absorption (TPA)-induced photoluminescence of two new MOFs based on a donor–acceptor tetraphenylphenylenediamine (tPPD) chromophore linker (H4TPBD) and Zn­(II) and Cd­(II) as metal centers. The TPA efficiencies are controlled by the network topologies, degree of interpenetration, packing densities, and the specific spatial arrangement of the chromophores. The effects can be rationalized within the framework of established excited-state theories of molecular crystals. The results presented here demonstrate the key effect of chromophore orientation on the nonlinear optical properties of crystalline network compounds and allow for establishing quantitative design principles for efficient TPA materials.
elements.clean_text: Coordination polymers show great potential for the tailored design of advanced photonic applications by employing crystal chemistry concepts. One challenge for achieving a rational design of nonlinear optically active MOF materials is deriving fundamental structure-property relations of the interplay between the photonic properties and the spatial arrangements of optically active chromophores within the network. We here investigate two-photon-absorption (TPA)-induced photoluminescence of two new MOFs based on a donor-acceptor tetraphenylphenylenediamine (tPPD) chromophore linker (H4TPBD) and Zn(II) and Cd(II) as metal centers. The TPA efficiencies are controlled by the network topologies, degree of interpenetration, packing densities, and the specific spatial arrangement of the chromophores. The effects can be rationalized within the framework of established excited-state theories of molecular crystals. The results presented here demonstrate the key effect of chromophore orientation on the nonlinear optical properties of crystalline network compounds and allow for establishing quantitative design principles for efficient TPA materials.

elements.content: Electronic excitations in molecular assemblies of optically active molecules are of fundamental interest in the field of optoelectronic applications. Since intermolecular interactions dominate the photophysical response in the crystalline phase, optical properties such as exciton lifetime, delocalization, and migration can be specifically tuned by the packing arrangement of chromophoric building blocks. At the same time, aggregates of self-assembled chromophores similarly give rise to large optical nonlinearities, which hold great promise in optical and quantum information technologies. Therefore, the directed assembly of chromophores in the solid state is desirable and has proved to be challenging in the past.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Electronic excitations in molecular assemblies of optically active molecules are of fundamental interest in the field of optoelectronic applications. Since intermolecular interactions dominate the photophysical response in the crystalline phase, optical properties such as exciton lifetime, delocalization, and migration can be specifically tuned by the packing arrangement of chromophoric building blocks. At the same time, aggregates of self-assembled chromophores similarly give rise to large optical nonlinearities, which hold great promise in optical and quantum information technologies. Therefore, the directed assembly of chromophores in the solid state is desirable and has proved to be challenging in the past.

elements.content: In this regard, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) appear as new materials for photonic applications, due to their modular building principle (organic linkers and metallic nodes), which allows for vast opportunities of material design. Consequently, in addition to the traditional research areas such as catalysis and gas storage and separation, MOFs (and related crystalline coordination polymers, CPs) have also been investigated toward possible applications in optoelectronics or nonlinear optics (NLO). The use of chromophore molecules as linkers allows for their controlled spatial arrangement in the solid state and in turn for accessing excitonic coupling by use of reticular chemistry principles (size of the linker, connectivity, and topology). Consequently, crystalline coordination networks of chromophores constitute an ideal platform for the development of molecular solid-state materials holding specific photophysical properties such as efficient exciton hopping, anisotropic energy transfer, amplified stimulated emission, or high absorption efficiencies.
elements.clean_text: In this regard, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) appear as new materials for photonic applications, due to their modular building principle (organic linkers and metallic nodes), which allows for vast opportunities of material design. Consequently, in addition to the traditional research areas such as catalysis and gas storage and separation, MOFs (and related crystalline coordination polymers, CPs) have also been investigated toward possible applications in optoelectronics or nonlinear optics (NLO). The use of chromophore molecules as linkers allows for their controlled spatial arrangement in the solid state and in turn for accessing excitonic coupling by use of reticular chemistry principles (size of the linker, connectivity, and topology). Consequently, crystalline coordination networks of chromophores constitute an ideal platform for the development of molecular solid-state materials holding specific photophysical properties such as efficient exciton hopping, anisotropic energy transfer, amplified stimulated emission, or high absorption efficiencies.

elements.content: Multiphoton absorption (MPA) is an NLO upconversion process playing a key role in the fields of high density data storage, optical limiting/lasing, and bioimaging and is therefore in the focus of current material research. In multichromophoric aggregates and solid-state materials several mechanisms for enhanced MPA response have been discussed: e.g., enhancement via increased conjugation between subunits (“through-bond”) or via intermolecular (excitonic) interactions between single chromophores (“through-space”). The latter is the focus of recent research, as enhancing the NLO response as a result of aggregation can open new ways for the realization of efficient MPA absorbers. Cooperative effects elicited by the close proximity of ligand molecules are also considered to be responsible for strong NLO response in MOFs; however, these still lack experimental evidence. Directed intermolecular interactions in MOFs and CPs can constitute an efficient way to tune their NLO response.
elements.clean_text: Multiphoton absorption (MPA) is an NLO upconversion process playing a key role in the fields of high density data storage, optical limiting/lasing, and bioimaging and is therefore in the focus of current material research. In multichromophoric aggregates and solid-state materials several mechanisms for enhanced MPA response have been discussed: e.g., enhancement via increased conjugation between subunits ("through-bond") or via intermolecular (excitonic) interactions between single chromophores ("through-space"). The latter is the focus of recent research, as enhancing the NLO response as a result of aggregation can open new ways for the realization of efficient MPA absorbers. Cooperative effects elicited by the close proximity of ligand molecules are also considered to be responsible for strong NLO response in MOFs; however, these still lack experimental evidence. Directed intermolecular interactions in MOFs and CPs can constitute an efficient way to tune their NLO response.

elements.content: For instance, we recently demonstrated MPA with exceptionally high cross-section values in a series of tetrakisphenylethylene-based MOFs, as a function of the topological network and changes in the local linker conformation.
elements.clean_text: For instance, we recently demonstrated MPA with exceptionally high cross-section values in a series of tetrakisphenylethylene-based MOFs, as a function of the topological network and changes in the local linker conformation.

elements.content: In this work, we employ triphenylamine-derived linkers as building blocks (H4TPBD), which are A−π–D push–pull type ligands (A = acceptor, D = donor), facilitating a strong intramolecular charge transfer (). The centrosymmetric multipolar geometry, featuring a phenylenediamine core (D) and four biphenyl carboxylic acid groups (A), leads to an enhanced polarizability, a prerequisite for strong NLO response. Zn­(II) and Cd­(II) as d10 metal ions were used to exclude a potential involvement of the nodes in the photophysical processes. Two new crystalline frameworks were synthesized under solvothermal conditions and subsequently intensely characterized toward their structural parameters and nonlinear absorption. The results were then analyzed to identify a potential structure–property relationship including possible existing cooperative enhancement effects (“through-space”) toward MPA in the coordination polymers, aiming at an understanding of the underlying mechanisms and trying to unravel effects in the NLO response of chromophore coordination networks.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we employ triphenylamine-derived linkers as building blocks (H4TPBD), which are A-π-D push-pull type ligands (A = acceptor, D = donor), facilitating a strong intramolecular charge transfer (). The centrosymmetric multipolar geometry, featuring a phenylenediamine core (D) and four biphenyl carboxylic acid groups (A), leads to an enhanced polarizability, a prerequisite for strong NLO response. Zn(II) and Cd(II) as d10 metal ions were used to exclude a potential involvement of the nodes in the photophysical processes. Two new crystalline frameworks were synthesized under solvothermal conditions and subsequently intensely characterized toward their structural parameters and nonlinear absorption. The results were then analyzed to identify a potential structure-property relationship including possible existing cooperative enhancement effects ("through-space") toward MPA in the coordination polymers, aiming at an understanding of the underlying mechanisms and trying to unravel effects in the NLO response of chromophore coordination networks.

elements.content:
TDMs are according to TD-DFT calculations. Color scheme: blue, nitrogen donor; red, carboxy-acceptor group.

Results and DiscussionSynthesis and Characterization

The push–pull chromophore tetrakis­(1,1′-biphenyl-4-carboxylic acid)-1,4-benzenediamine (H4TPBD, ) was synthesized in a three-step reaction procedure starting from N′,N″,N′′′,N′′′′-tetraphenylbenzene-1,4-diamine. The synthetic procedure and structural and characterization details are provided in the Supporting Information. The reaction of H4TPBD with Zn­(NO3)2·4H2O in a dimethylacetamide (DMAc)/H2O mixture at 100 °C yielded pale yellow X-ray-quality single crystals of a fluorescent two-dimensional framework with the composition [Zn2(TPBD)­(DMAc)2] (tPPD-Zn, and Figures S14–S17; see the Supporting Information for details on structure elucidation). The two-dimensional framework crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c and is composed of a four-connecting (4-c) Zn2+ node (c) and the ligand TPBD (b and ). The secondary building unit (SBU) contains two zinc atoms which are connected by four TPBD ligand motifs and two DMAc molecules. Each zinc atom is pentacoordinated in a distorted-square-pyramidal coordination environment consisting of three carboxylate groups and one DMAc solvent molecule. One carboxylate group coordinates in a bidentate asymmetrical chelating fashion, whereas the two other carboxylic groups bridge the two zinc atoms in a κ1:κ1 mode, leading to a rhombic node structure (c). Topology analysis of tPPD-Zn using the ToposPro software package classified the materials as a twofold interpenetrated uninodal (4,4)-network of sql topology (d and Figure S15). The compound adopts a herringbone type packing of the TPBD ligand within the crystallographic bc plane with stacking along the b and c axes, respectively (c and Figure S17). The stacking molecules show coplanar ordering with distances of 10.0 and 15.1 Å (center to center distance of the p-phenylenediamine cores). The phase purity, stability against different solvents, and the long-term stability of the bulk tPPD-Zn were investigated by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD, Figures S7–S9), matching the results from single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) analysis. The compound is thermally stable up to 440 °C (thermogravimetric analysis, TGA; Figure S5). Infrared (IR) and Raman spectroscopy show the expected bands for coordinated TPBD (Figures S23 and S24).

Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

The push-pull chromophore tetrakis(1,1'-biphenyl-4-carboxylic acid)-1,4-benzenediamine (H4TPBD, ) was synthesized in a three-step reaction procedure starting from N',N",N''',N''''-tetraphenylbenzene-1,4-diamine. The synthetic procedure and structural and characterization details are provided in the Supporting Information. The reaction of H4TPBD with Zn(NO3)2⋅4H2O in a dimethylacetamide (DMAc)/H2O mixture at 100 °C yielded pale yellow X-ray-quality single crystals of a fluorescent two-dimensional framework with the composition [Zn2(TPBD)(DMAc)2] (tPPD-Zn,  and Figures S14-S17; see the Supporting Information for details on structure elucidation). The two-dimensional framework crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c and is composed of a four-connecting (4-c) Zn2+ node (c) and the ligand TPBD (b and ). The secondary building unit (SBU) contains two zinc atoms which are connected by four TPBD ligand motifs and two DMAc molecules. Each zinc atom is pentacoordinated in a distorted-square-pyramidal coordination environment consisting of three carboxylate groups and one DMAc solvent molecule. One carboxylate group coordinates in a bidentate asymmetrical chelating fashion, whereas the two other carboxylic groups bridge the two zinc atoms in a κ1:κ1 mode, leading to a rhombic node structure (c). Topology analysis of tPPD-Zn using the ToposPro software package classified the materials as a twofold interpenetrated uninodal (4,4)-network of sql topology (d and Figure S15). The compound adopts a herringbone type packing of the TPBD ligand within the crystallographic bc plane with stacking along the b and c axes, respectively (c and Figure S17). The stacking molecules show coplanar ordering with distances of 10.0 and 15.1 Å (center to center distance of the p-phenylenediamine cores). The phase purity, stability against different solvents, and the long-term stability of the bulk tPPD-Zn were investigated by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD, Figures S7-S9), matching the results from single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) analysis. The compound is thermally stable up to 440 °C (thermogravimetric analysis, TGA; Figure S5). Infrared (IR) and Raman spectroscopy show the expected bands for coordinated TPBD (Figures S23 and S24).

(c) The Zn2+-containing SBU (oxygen, red; nitrogen, blue; carbon, gray; zinc, turquoise), (d) Underlying network topology of tPPD-Zn. (e) Interpenetration of the two sql networks.

(c) The Zn2+-containing SBU (oxygen, red; nitrogen, blue; carbon, gray; zinc, turquoise), (d) Underlying network topology of tPPD-Zn. (e) Interpenetration of the two sql networks.

elements.content: The reaction of H4TPBD with Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O under solvothermal conditions similar to those for tPPD-Zn yielded pale yellow crystals of a fluorescent three-dimensional framework with the composition [Cd2(TPBD)­(H2O)4] (tPPD-Cd, and Figures S18–S21). Single crystals suitable for X-ray structure analysis were obtained directly from the synthesis (see the Supporting Information for details on structure elucidation and synthetic procedure). The three-dimensional framework tPPD-Cd crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ and is built up by a four-connecting (4-c) Cd2+ node unit and the ligand TPBD (b,c). The node contains two cadmium atoms which are coordinated by four carboxylate groups and four water molecules. One Cd2+ cation is hexacoordinated in a bidentate fashion by two carboxylates and two water molecules. The cadmium atoms are bridged by two carboxylates. Interestingly, the rhombic node of tPPD-Zn resembles that in tPPD-Cd (c). Topology analysis revealed a 3-fold interpenetrated uninodal (4,4)-network showing cds topology (d and Figure S19). As in the monoclinic tPPD-Zn, the triclinic tPPD-Cd adopts a herringbone type packing within the crystallographic ab plane with stacking along the a and b axes (d and Figure S21). The chromophores of tPPD-Cd show coplanar stacking with center to center distances of 11.5 and 10.9 Å. The phase purity and solvent and long-term stability of the bulk material were confirmed by PXRD and TGA measurements (Figures S6 and S10–S12). Comparison of the IR and Raman spectra with those of the free ligand H4TPBD showed the characteristic bands, proving the successful incorporation of the linker in the Cd-MOF (Figures S23 and S24). Thermal stability was proofed by TGA measurements, which revealed thermal stability up to 400 °C (Figure S6).
elements.clean_text: The reaction of H4TPBD with Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O under solvothermal conditions similar to those for tPPD-Zn yielded pale yellow crystals of a fluorescent three-dimensional framework with the composition [Cd2(TPBD)(H2O)4] (tPPD-Cd,  and Figures S18-S21). Single crystals suitable for X-ray structure analysis were obtained directly from the synthesis (see the Supporting Information for details on structure elucidation and synthetic procedure). The three-dimensional framework tPPD-Cd crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ and is built up by a four-connecting (4-c) Cd2+ node unit and the ligand TPBD (b,c). The node contains two cadmium atoms which are coordinated by four carboxylate groups and four water molecules. One Cd2+ cation is hexacoordinated in a bidentate fashion by two carboxylates and two water molecules. The cadmium atoms are bridged by two carboxylates. Interestingly, the rhombic node of tPPD-Zn resembles that in tPPD-Cd (c). Topology analysis revealed a 3-fold interpenetrated uninodal (4,4)-network showing cds topology (d and Figure S19). As in the monoclinic tPPD-Zn, the triclinic tPPD-Cd adopts a herringbone type packing within the crystallographic ab plane with stacking along the a and b axes (d and Figure S21). The chromophores of tPPD-Cd show coplanar stacking with center to center distances of 11.5 and 10.9 Å. The phase purity and solvent and long-term stability of the bulk material were confirmed by PXRD and TGA measurements (Figures S6 and S10-S12). Comparison of the IR and Raman spectra with those of the free ligand H4TPBD showed the characteristic bands, proving the successful incorporation of the linker in the Cd-MOF (Figures S23 and S24). Thermal stability was proofed by TGA measurements, which revealed thermal stability up to 400 °C (Figure S6).

(c) The Cd2+-containing SBU (oxygen, red; carbon, gray; cadmium, green). (d) Underlying network topology of tPPD-Cd. (e) Interpenetration of the three cds networks.

(c) The Cd2+-containing SBU (oxygen, red; carbon, gray; cadmium, green). (d) Underlying network topology of tPPD-Cd. (e) Interpenetration of the three cds networks.

elements.content: The reaction of the four-connecting linker H4TPBD with group 12 metal ions yields structurally closely related uninodal (4,4)-networks; however, the reaction with Zn2+ delivers a regular 2D net (sql, Figure S15), whereas the reaction with Cd2+ gives a 3D rod net (cds, Figure S19). The in situ formed metal–oxo bimetallic nodes show a rhombic-planar symmetry (c and c and Figures S14 and S18). Both network compounds show different grades of interpenetration: 2-fold for tPPD-Zn (e) and 3-fold for tPPD-Cd (e). Importantly, the local ligand distortions of TPBD in tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd caused by the coordination bond formation and the framework integration are similar, as proved by Raman spectroscopy and by comparison of molecular structures from SCXRD (Figure S22). Although both materials hold different underlying topologies, the coordination networks show the same herringbone arrangements of the chromophores, however with a quite significantly shorter distance between coplanar TPBD molecules in tPPD-Cd (∼24% reduction along the a axis, c,d) engendered by the higher grade of network interpenetration. This specific structural characteristic of the chromophore packing will result in a pronounced difference in the linear and nonlinear optical properties of the network compounds, as we show in the following sections. Consequently, network interpenetration in MOFs should be considered as a further tool for tuning the MPA properties of this material class.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of the four-connecting linker H4TPBD with group 12 metal ions yields structurally closely related uninodal (4,4)-networks; however, the reaction with Zn2+ delivers a regular 2D net (sql, Figure S15), whereas the reaction with Cd2+ gives a 3D rod net (cds, Figure S19). The in situ formed metal-oxo bimetallic nodes show a rhombic-planar symmetry (c and c and Figures S14 and S18). Both network compounds show different grades of interpenetration: 2-fold for tPPD-Zn (e) and 3-fold for tPPD-Cd (e). Importantly, the local ligand distortions of TPBD in tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd caused by the coordination bond formation and the framework integration are similar, as proved by Raman spectroscopy and by comparison of molecular structures from SCXRD (Figure S22). Although both materials hold different underlying topologies, the coordination networks show the same herringbone arrangements of the chromophores, however with a quite significantly shorter distance between coplanar TPBD molecules in tPPD-Cd (~24% reduction along the a axis, c,d) engendered by the higher grade of network interpenetration. This specific structural characteristic of the chromophore packing will result in a pronounced difference in the linear and nonlinear optical properties of the network compounds, as we show in the following sections. Consequently, network interpenetration in MOFs should be considered as a further tool for tuning the MPA properties of this material class.

elements.content: With the ligand and two new framework compounds in hand, we conducted steady-state optical measurements on all compounds. The UV–vis spectrum of H4TPBD shows an absorption band located at 372 nm (Figure S25). Upon excitation at the maximum of the absorption band in DMF solution, H4TPBD shows a photoluminescence (PL) centered at 573 nm with an overall asymmetric shape in the spectrum (Figure S26). The molecule exhibits an external quantum yield of Φex(H4TPBD) = 0.19 and a large Stokes shift of ∼200 nm. Time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) calculations reproduced the main transitions, which correspond to the absorption band at 372 nm, as HOMO → LUMO+2 (S1, Au state) and HOMO → LUMO+1 (S2, Bu state) transitions (details of the calculations are provided in the Supporting Information). On the basis of this information the absorption band can be assigned to a dispersed π–π* excitation located in the biphenyl rings with partial charge transfer between the triphenylamine and carboxylic acid groups, proving H4TPBD to be a multipolar A−π–D push–pull chromophore. To understand the influence of chromophore aggregation on the emissive properties of the ligand, we measured photoluminescence excitation (PLE) spectra of H4TPBD at different concentrations. Upon increases in the concentration the PLE signals drastically shift, which points toward the formation of different photoactive aggregates (possible J and H aggregates) and supports the potential excitonic character of H4TPBD (see the discussion in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Steady-State Optical Analysis and Excitonic Coupling Picture

With the ligand and two new framework compounds in hand, we conducted steady-state optical measurements on all compounds. The UV-vis spectrum of H4TPBD shows an absorption band located at 372 nm (Figure S25). Upon excitation at the maximum of the absorption band in DMF solution, H4TPBD shows a photoluminescence (PL) centered at 573 nm with an overall asymmetric shape in the spectrum (Figure S26). The molecule exhibits an external quantum yield of Φex(H4TPBD) = 0.19 and a large Stokes shift of ~200 nm. Time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) calculations reproduced the main transitions, which correspond to the absorption band at 372 nm, as HOMO → LUMO+2 (S1, Au state) and HOMO → LUMO+1 (S2, Bu state) transitions (details of the calculations are provided in the Supporting Information). On the basis of this information the absorption band can be assigned to a dispersed π-π* excitation located in the biphenyl rings with partial charge transfer between the triphenylamine and carboxylic acid groups, proving H4TPBD to be a multipolar A-π-D push-pull chromophore. To understand the influence of chromophore aggregation on the emissive properties of the ligand, we measured photoluminescence excitation (PLE) spectra of H4TPBD at different concentrations. Upon increases in the concentration the PLE signals drastically shift, which points toward the formation of different photoactive aggregates (possible J and H aggregates) and supports the potential excitonic character of H4TPBD (see the discussion in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: The absorption and reflectance spectra of tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd show a distinct gas to crystal shift in comparison to H4TPBD with the absorption edges located at ∼483 nm (tPPD-Zn) and ∼506 nm (tPPD-Cd, Figures S62–S67). The PL spectra show emission centered at ∼520 nm for tPPD-Zn and ∼521 nm for tPPD-Cd (λex = 400 nm, Figures S31 and S35). The determined external quantum yields amount to Φ­(tPPD-Zn) = 0.24 and Φ­(tPPD-Cd) = 0.52. The PL spectra of these compounds were also analyzed using high-fluence femtosecond laser pulses as excitation with a repetition rate of 1 kHz. In this case, the PL intensities were recorded using a fiber-coupled CCD spectrometer. Due to the higher resolution of this detector, the femtosecond laser excited photoluminescence showed several well-resolved peaks in the emission of tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd, which were deconvoluted in its single fractions using Gaussian distribution functions (Figures S33 and S37). The assignment and fitting of the contributions to a vibronic progression of high-frequency phenyl/ring stretching modes (∼1600 cm–1) show good agreement between the calculated and measured PL spectra (see the Supporting Information for details on the vibronic analysis). We wish to note that such features are common in absorption and emission spectra of organic conjugated compounds. To further investigate the origin of the PL, we also conducted PLE measurements, focusing on the maximum and a lower and higher wavelength within the emission range (see arrows in ). As in the case of the more highly concentrated ligand solutions (10–3 mol/L, and Figure S28), we observed an additional red-shifted band centered at ∼450 nm. This implies that, similarly to the linker in higher concentrated solutions, also in the coordination networks the emission originates from various feeding states over the whole emission range holding excitonic character. Both compounds adopt a herringbone type packing with two molecules of TPBD per unit cell, which would allow for Coulombic excitonic coupling within the weak exciton-coupling regime. For a characteristic dimeric chromophore structure, if noncoplanar aligned transition dipole moments (TDMs) of two translationally invariant molecules in a primitive unit cell couple, transitions to the upper and lower dimer components are allowed simultaneously. Note that, in the present case, the absorption band of H4TPBD is composed of two orthogonal transitions according to TD-DFT (TDMs along the molecular x and y axes, ), which would lead to six possible coupling modes (Figure S61). By applying a simple dipole–dipole interaction model for herringbone type dimers as a first approximation, we calculated the expected splitting energies V dipole on the basis of geometric parameters extracted from the SC-XRD structures ( and Figures S59 and S60 and Table S12; a detailed analysis of exciton coupling is given in the Supporting Information). The calculated splitting energies are in good accordance with the measured values from excitation, reflectance, and absorption spectra, reproducing the found red shifts in comparison to the single ligand chromophore. We further conducted a series of TD-DFT calculations on several TPBD clusters (dimer and trimer structure aggregates) extracted from the respective crystal structures (see Supporting Information for details). Excited-state properties of the TPBD clusters were assessed by simulation of the electronic absorption spectra and by analyzing atomic-centered transition density matrices. The latter reveal weakly bound non-polar excitonic states with an exciton radius of up to three chromophore units. The excitonic analysis applying dipole–dipole coupling is recovered in the TD-DFT calculations; however, the simulations demonstrate that intermolecular interactions in the coordination network materials will go beyond pure electrostatic interactions and charge-separated states will also influence the photoresponse (see the discussion in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: The absorption and reflectance spectra of tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd show a distinct gas to crystal shift in comparison to H4TPBD with the absorption edges located at ~483 nm (tPPD-Zn) and ~506 nm (tPPD-Cd, Figures S62-S67). The PL spectra show emission centered at ~520 nm for tPPD-Zn and ~521 nm for tPPD-Cd (λex = 400 nm, Figures S31 and S35). The determined external quantum yields amount to Φ(tPPD-Zn) = 0.24 and Φ(tPPD-Cd) = 0.52. The PL spectra of these compounds were also analyzed using high-fluence femtosecond laser pulses as excitation with a repetition rate of 1 kHz. In this case, the PL intensities were recorded using a fiber-coupled CCD spectrometer. Due to the higher resolution of this detector, the femtosecond laser excited photoluminescence showed several well-resolved peaks in the emission of tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd, which were deconvoluted in its single fractions using Gaussian distribution functions (Figures S33 and S37). The assignment and fitting of the contributions to a vibronic progression of high-frequency phenyl/ring stretching modes (~1600 cm-1) show good agreement between the calculated and measured PL spectra (see the Supporting Information for details on the vibronic analysis). We wish to note that such features are common in absorption and emission spectra of organic conjugated compounds. To further investigate the origin of the PL, we also conducted PLE measurements, focusing on the maximum and a lower and higher wavelength within the emission range (see arrows in ). As in the case of the more highly concentrated ligand solutions (10-3 mol/L,  and Figure S28), we observed an additional red-shifted band centered at ~450 nm. This implies that, similarly to the linker in higher concentrated solutions, also in the coordination networks the emission originates from various feeding states over the whole emission range holding excitonic character. Both compounds adopt a herringbone type packing with two molecules of TPBD per unit cell, which would allow for Coulombic excitonic coupling within the weak exciton-coupling regime. For a characteristic dimeric chromophore structure, if noncoplanar aligned transition dipole moments (TDMs) of two translationally invariant molecules in a primitive unit cell couple, transitions to the upper and lower dimer components are allowed simultaneously. Note that, in the present case, the absorption band of H4TPBD is composed of two orthogonal transitions according to TD-DFT (TDMs along the molecular x and y axes, ), which would lead to six possible coupling modes (Figure S61). By applying a simple dipole-dipole interaction model for herringbone type dimers as a first approximation, we calculated the expected splitting energies V dipole on the basis of geometric parameters extracted from the SC-XRD structures ( and Figures S59 and S60 and Table S12; a detailed analysis of exciton coupling is given in the Supporting Information). The calculated splitting energies are in good accordance with the measured values from excitation, reflectance, and absorption spectra, reproducing the found red shifts in comparison to the single ligand chromophore. We further conducted a series of TD-DFT calculations on several TPBD clusters (dimer and trimer structure aggregates) extracted from the respective crystal structures (see Supporting Information for details). Excited-state properties of the TPBD clusters were assessed by simulation of the electronic absorption spectra and by analyzing atomic-centered transition density matrices. The latter reveal weakly bound non-polar excitonic states with an exciton radius of up to three chromophore units. The excitonic analysis applying dipole-dipole coupling is recovered in the TD-DFT calculations; however, the simulations demonstrate that intermolecular interactions in the coordination network materials will go beyond pure electrostatic interactions and charge-separated states will also influence the photoresponse (see the discussion in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: To sum up, the previous analysis suggests the existence of excitonically coupled states with strong delocalization and distinct charge-transfer characteristics. Such excitonic interactions in chromophore assemblies have been discussed as enhancement mechanisms to strong cooperative NLO response, and we consequently expect a pronounced structure relation toward the TPA response of tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd. To prove this working hypothesis, we focused on their nonlinear absorption properties, namely the two-photon excited fluorescence (TPEF) spectra in a spectral region close to that of one-photon resonance.
elements.clean_text: To sum up, the previous analysis suggests the existence of excitonically coupled states with strong delocalization and distinct charge-transfer characteristics. Such excitonic interactions in chromophore assemblies have been discussed as enhancement mechanisms to strong cooperative NLO response, and we consequently expect a pronounced structure relation toward the TPA response of tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd. To prove this working hypothesis, we focused on their nonlinear absorption properties, namely the two-photon excited fluorescence (TPEF) spectra in a spectral region close to that of one-photon resonance.

elements.content: Below band gap optical excitation of tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd was studied using an excitation source at λex = 800 nm. The excitation energy for two-photon absorption (TPA) was provided by a femtosecond laser with 100 fs pulses at a repetition rate of 1 kHz. We observe a PL centered around ∼520 nm, with no shift in comparison to the measured linear PL (a,b). Since linear absorption at the excitation wavelength is negligible, the absorption process is of nonlinear origin, indicating a TPA process. The absence of a real accessible energy level at 800 nm shows that the absorption process must proceed via a virtual state, which excludes resonance enhancement effects in the TPA properties. Interestingly, we observe the same vibronic replicas as in the linear case (discussed above), showing that the nonlinear absorption in the network compounds proceeds via linker-centered states. To gain information about the order of the NLO absorption, power-dependent measurements were carried out. Since the probability of NLO absorption is a power function of the excitation fluence, the intensity of the luminescence follows a power law. Thus, by measuring the PL intensity as a function of excitation intensity, one can obtain the order of the NLO absorption. We find that a power 2 process takes place with excitation at 800 nm, identifying TPA as the underlying NLO process ( ). The network compounds show stability against high-power illumination with excitation fluences in the mJ/cm2 region, however, with clear signs of photosaturation.
elements.clean_text:
Two-Photon-Absorption-Induced Photoluminescence

Below band gap optical excitation of tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd was studied using an excitation source at λex = 800 nm. The excitation energy for two-photon absorption (TPA) was provided by a femtosecond laser with 100 fs pulses at a repetition rate of 1 kHz. We observe a PL centered around ~520 nm, with no shift in comparison to the measured linear PL (a,b). Since linear absorption at the excitation wavelength is negligible, the absorption process is of nonlinear origin, indicating a TPA process. The absence of a real accessible energy level at 800 nm shows that the absorption process must proceed via a virtual state, which excludes resonance enhancement effects in the TPA properties. Interestingly, we observe the same vibronic replicas as in the linear case (discussed above), showing that the nonlinear absorption in the network compounds proceeds via linker-centered states. To gain information about the order of the NLO absorption, power-dependent measurements were carried out. Since the probability of NLO absorption is a power function of the excitation fluence, the intensity of the luminescence follows a power law. Thus, by measuring the PL intensity as a function of excitation intensity, one can obtain the order of the NLO absorption. We find that a power 2 process takes place with excitation at 800 nm, identifying TPA as the underlying NLO process ( ). The network compounds show stability against high-power illumination with excitation fluences in the mJ/cm2 region, however, with clear signs of photosaturation.

elements.content: (a, b) Two-photon excited fluorescence spectra of tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd at different excitation powers. (c, d) Integrated photoluminescence as a function of the laser excitation intensity for tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd showing a quadratic behavior from which the order of the process (two-photon absorption at 800 nm excitation) can be deduced.

(c, d) Integrated photoluminescence as a function of the laser excitation intensity for tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd showing a quadratic behavior from which the order of the process (two-photon absorption at 800 nm excitation) can be deduced.

elements.content: We now turn our attention to the structure–property relation of TPA in the two coordination networks. A relative estimate about the enhancement of the TPA properties of tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd can be obtained by a comparison of their integrated TPEF areas at similar excitation powers (). σ tPPD‐Cd TPA σ tPPD‐Zn TPA = ξ = A tPPD‐Cd d tPPD‐Zn φ tPPD‐Zn A tPPD‐Zn d tPPD‐Cd φ tPPD‐Cd where σ is the TPA cross-section, A is the integrated TPEF area normalized by the integration time, d is the chromophore density (number of linkers per unit cell), and φ is the quantum efficiency of the respective network compounds. By using the solid-state TPEF method, we found an enhancement factor of ξ = 9 for the TPA cross-sections of tPPD-Cd in comparison to tPPD-Zn (b, Table S5 and ). Key elements for enhanced two-photon absorptivity in aggregates and solid-state materials have been described to originate from an increase in the number of active centers and by coherent interactions between the single chromophores via conjugation (“through bond”) or “through-space” (excitonic) interactions. tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd both exhibit slightly different chromophore densities (tPPD-Zn, 1.00 mol/dm3; tPPD-Cd, 1.19 mol/dm3), and therefore we would only expect slightly higher TPEF areas for tPPD-Cd, provided that no intermolecular interactions among neighboring chromophores exist and the NLO response is only limited by the number of active centers. The higher grade of network interpenetration in tPPD-Cd results in lower distances of neighboring TPBD molecules (decrease of ∼24% for coplanar TPBD stacking c,d). This fact seems to dramatically affect the TPA properties of the two CPs. Apparently, the difference in the electronic structure, being a function of the local chromophore arrangement, alters the NLO response. TPA scaling via excitonic coupling only takes place in a spectral region close to one-photon resonance, because of the respective exciton splitting energies (V ≈ 1000 cm–1, ). Excitation at an 800 nm wavelength corresponds to 400 nm absorption, which is close to the absorption band of H4TPBD (372 nm). Consequently, below band gap states of excitonic character are addressed during two-photon excitation (two-photon resonance with excitonic states; ). Furthermore, the PLE analysis of H4TPBD (Figures S26–S28) and the CPs as well as the DFT results suggest that these states hold J-type character (∼450 nm, b) and are more pronounced in the case of tPPD-Cd, which shows an enhanced TPA response. TPA scaling in J-type aggregates has been reported for porphyrins or pseudoisocyanine dyes to occur via coherent exciton delocalization. In contrast, even though it exhibits the same principal packing motif, in tPPD-Zn the chromophore arrangement is different, which seems to negatively affect the TPA properties. We ascribe this fact to a conceivably higher exciton coherence in tPPD-Cd. In summary, higher chromophore density, denser packing, and stronger excitonic interactions cooperatively achieve a significant TPA enhancement in tPPD-Cd in comparison to tPPD-Zn by approximately 1 order of magnitude (, details on TPA analysis in the Supporting Information). We thus argue that the observed increase in the two-photon response is related to a predominantly “through-space” enhancement mechanism, induced by tighter and specifically packed chromophores as a direct consequence of a higher grade of network interpenetration within tPPD-Cd. The recent results, although not fully conclusive, consolidate that excitonic coupling can constitute an active mechanism in crystalline coordination polymers for the enhancement of the two-photon absorptivity by excitation in a spectral region close to one-photon resonance.
elements.clean_text: We now turn our attention to the structure-property relation of TPA in the two coordination networks. A relative estimate about the enhancement of the TPA properties of tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd can be obtained by a comparison of their integrated TPEF areas at similar excitation powers ().        σ   tPPD-Cd   TPA       σ   tPPD-Zn   TPA     = ξ =     A   tPPD-Cd     d   tPPD-Zn     φ   tPPD-Zn       A   tPPD-Zn     d   tPPD-Cd     φ   tPPD-Cd       1 where σ is the TPA cross-section, A is the integrated TPEF area normalized by the integration time, d is the chromophore density (number of linkers per unit cell), and φ is the quantum efficiency of the respective network compounds. By using the solid-state TPEF method, we found an enhancement factor of ξ = 9 for the TPA cross-sections of tPPD-Cd in comparison to tPPD-Zn (b, Table S5 and ). Key elements for enhanced two-photon absorptivity in aggregates and solid-state materials have been described to originate from an increase in the number of active centers and by coherent interactions between the single chromophores via conjugation ("through bond") or "through-space" (excitonic) interactions. tPPD-Zn and tPPD-Cd both exhibit slightly different chromophore densities (tPPD-Zn, 1.00 mol/dm3; tPPD-Cd, 1.19 mol/dm3), and therefore we would only expect slightly higher TPEF areas for tPPD-Cd, provided that no intermolecular interactions among neighboring chromophores exist and the NLO response is only limited by the number of active centers. The higher grade of network interpenetration in tPPD-Cd results in lower distances of neighboring TPBD molecules (decrease of ~24% for coplanar TPBD stacking c,d). This fact seems to dramatically affect the TPA properties of the two CPs. Apparently, the difference in the electronic structure, being a function of the local chromophore arrangement, alters the NLO response. TPA scaling via excitonic coupling only takes place in a spectral region close to one-photon resonance, because of the respective exciton splitting energies (V ~ 1000 cm-1, ). Excitation at an 800 nm wavelength corresponds to 400 nm absorption, which is close to the absorption band of H4TPBD (372 nm). Consequently, below band gap states of excitonic character are addressed during two-photon excitation (two-photon resonance with excitonic states; ). Furthermore, the PLE analysis of H4TPBD (Figures S26-S28) and the CPs as well as the DFT results suggest that these states hold J-type character (~450 nm, b) and are more pronounced in the case of tPPD-Cd, which shows an enhanced TPA response. TPA scaling in J-type aggregates has been reported for porphyrins or pseudoisocyanine dyes to occur via coherent exciton delocalization. In contrast, even though it exhibits the same principal packing motif, in tPPD-Zn the chromophore arrangement is different, which seems to negatively affect the TPA properties. We ascribe this fact to a conceivably higher exciton coherence in tPPD-Cd. In summary, higher chromophore density, denser packing, and stronger excitonic interactions cooperatively achieve a significant TPA enhancement in tPPD-Cd in comparison to tPPD-Zn by approximately 1 order of magnitude (, details on TPA analysis in the Supporting Information). We thus argue that the observed increase in the two-photon response is related to a predominantly "through-space" enhancement mechanism, induced by tighter and specifically packed chromophores as a direct consequence of a higher grade of network interpenetration within tPPD-Cd. The recent results, although not fully conclusive, consolidate that excitonic coupling can constitute an active mechanism in crystalline coordination polymers for the enhancement of the two-photon absorptivity by excitation in a spectral region close to one-photon resonance.

elements.content: We synthesized and structurally characterized two new fluorescent crystalline network compounds, namely the zinc-containing two-dimensional coordination polymer tPPD-Zn and the cadmium-based three-dimensional metal–organic framework tPPD-Cd, using a phenylenediamine-derived chromophore as a four-connecting ligand motif. Both materials possess uninodal (4,4)-network topologies (sql and cds) and show herringbone type packing motifs of the chromophore. By using static spectroscopic techniques, we investigated the materials toward their two-photon absorptivity and were able to show that a structure-related enhancement of the relative TPA cross-section is most probably associated with an enhanced “through-space” interaction in tPPD-Cd, which is a direct consequence of closer and specifically arranged chromophoric linker molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We synthesized and structurally characterized two new fluorescent crystalline network compounds, namely the zinc-containing two-dimensional coordination polymer tPPD-Zn and the cadmium-based three-dimensional metal-organic framework tPPD-Cd, using a phenylenediamine-derived chromophore as a four-connecting ligand motif. Both materials possess uninodal (4,4)-network topologies (sql and cds) and show herringbone type packing motifs of the chromophore. By using static spectroscopic techniques, we investigated the materials toward their two-photon absorptivity and were able to show that a structure-related enhancement of the relative TPA cross-section is most probably associated with an enhanced "through-space" interaction in tPPD-Cd, which is a direct consequence of closer and specifically arranged chromophoric linker molecules.

elements.content: The present study enabled us to derive quantitative information about the influence of packing density and chromophore arrangement on two-photon-absorption properties of photoactive metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and related materials. We used established excited-state theories of molecular crystals and aggregates to describe the photophysical response and correlated the findings with the TPA properties of the network compounds. Further studies extending the scope and the number of the investigated systems will be required to get a more complete understanding of the relevant phenomena. Importantly, the chromophore arrangement in dense (interpenetrated), typically less porous, or even nonporous coordination network compounds (MOFs and CPs) tuned out to be a key factor for the control of the NLO properties of these materials. With ongoing understanding of network interpenetration, the entwining of multiple layers can be regarded as a further tool for the rational design of highly MPA active coordination networks. Multichromophoric arrangements in MOFs and CPs oriented in a J-type assembly (face to tail arrangement) seem to be an interesting target structures for enhanced NLO response. Our results already demonstrate that such specific design of chromophore assemblies in crystalline network materials bears the potential to control the MPA properties, which ultimately can lead to superior MPA materials in comparison to existing materials and open new avenues for future work in this area, with perspectives ranging from bioimaging (e.g., MPA-active MOF nanoparticles) to photonic applications (e.g., all-optical switches in MOF nanocrystal waveguides).
elements.clean_text: The present study enabled us to derive quantitative information about the influence of packing density and chromophore arrangement on two-photon-absorption properties of photoactive metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and related materials. We used established excited-state theories of molecular crystals and aggregates to describe the photophysical response and correlated the findings with the TPA properties of the network compounds. Further studies extending the scope and the number of the investigated systems will be required to get a more complete understanding of the relevant phenomena. Importantly, the chromophore arrangement in dense (interpenetrated), typically less porous, or even nonporous coordination network compounds (MOFs and CPs) tuned out to be a key factor for the control of the NLO properties of these materials. With ongoing understanding of network interpenetration, the entwining of multiple layers can be regarded as a further tool for the rational design of highly MPA active coordination networks. Multichromophoric arrangements in MOFs and CPs oriented in a J-type assembly (face to tail arrangement) seem to be an interesting target structures for enhanced NLO response. Our results already demonstrate that such specific design of chromophore assemblies in crystalline network materials bears the potential to control the MPA properties, which ultimately can lead to superior MPA materials in comparison to existing materials and open new avenues for future work in this area, with perspectives ranging from bioimaging (e.g., MPA-active MOF nanoparticles) to photonic applications (e.g., all-optical switches in MOF nanocrystal waveguides).

metadata.title:
Controlling
Multiphoton Absorption Efficiency by Chromophore
Packing in Metal–Organic Frameworks
